quest_title: A horizontal telegraph wire 0.5 km long running east and west in a part of circuit whose resistance is 2.5 \(\Omega\). The wire falls to the ground from a height of 5 m. If \(\text{g}\) = 10 m/s\({}^{2}\) and \(\text{B}\) = 2 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-5}\) Tesla, then current induced in the circuit is
explanation_txt:
\(i=\cfrac{E}{R}=\cfrac{1}{R} \cfrac{d \phi}{d t} \)
\(\text { Here, } d \phi=B A=\left(2 \times 10^{-5}\right) \times\left(0.5 \times 10^{3} \times 5\right) \)
\(d t=\text { time taken by the wire to fall at ground } \)
\(d t=\left(\cfrac{2 h}{g}\right)^{1 / 2}=\left(\cfrac{10}{10}\right)^{1 / 2}=1 \mathrm{sec} \)
\(i=\cfrac{1}{2.5} \cfrac{\left[\left(2 \times 10^{-5}\right) \times\left(0.5 \times 10^{3} \times 5\right)\right]}{1} \)
\(i=0.02 \mathrm{A} \)

quest_title:
The electronic structure of four elements A, B, C and D are  
 \(\begin{array}{ll}{\mathrm{A}=1 \mathrm{s}^{2}} & {\mathrm{B}=1 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{p}^{2}} \\ {\mathrm{C}=1 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{p}^{5}} & {\mathrm{D}=1 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{s}^{2} 2 \mathrm{p}^{6}}\end{array}\) 
 The tendency to form the electrovalent bond is greatest in
explanation_txt:
A. the s has 2 out of 2 electrons, thus orbital is complete

B. the p orbital has 2 out of 6 electrons, tendency to lose two electrons

C. the p orbital has 5 out of 6 electrons, tendency to gain one elctrons

D. the p orbital has 6 out of 6 electrons, thus complete

 

Thus, 'C' has the greatest tendency to form electrovalent bond.
question_plain_title: The electronic structure of four elements A, B, C and D are The tendency to form the electrovalent bond is greatest in
explanation_plain_text:
A. the s has 2 out of 2 electrons, thus orbital is complete

B. the p orbital has 2 out of 6 electrons, tendency to lose two electrons

C. the p orbital has 5 out of 6 electrons, tendency to gain one elctrons

D. the p orbital has 6 out of 6 electrons, thus complete

 

Thus, 'C' has the greatest tendency to form electrovalent bond.

quest_title: The number of solutions of \( e^{2x} +e^x -6= 0 \) is:
explanation_txt:
The given equation is quadratic in \(e^x\)

Let, \(y = e^x \) and solve for \(y\)

\( \begin{align} y & = \cfrac{-1 \pm \sqrt{1+24}}{2} \\ & = \cfrac {-1 \pm 5}{2} \\ & = 2, -3 \end{align} \)

But, \(e^x \) can't be negative.

So, there is ONE solution and that is \( x = ln2 \).

quest_title: If \(a , b , c\) are unequal what is the condition that the value of the following determinant is zero \(\Delta = \left| \begin{array} { c c c } { a } & { a ^ { 2 } } & { a ^ { 3 } + 1 } \\ { b } & { b ^ { 2 } } & { b ^ { 3 } + 1 } \\ { c } & { c ^ { 2 } } & { c ^ { 3 } } { + 1 } \end{array} \right|\)
explanation_txt:
Splitting the determinant into two determinants, we get,

\( \Delta = \left| \begin{array} { l l l } { 1 } & { a } & { a ^ { 2 } } \\ { 1 } & { b } & { b ^ { 2 } } \\ { 1 } & { c } & { c ^ { 2 } } \end{array} \right| + a b c \left| \begin{array} { l l l } { 1 } & { a } & { a ^ { 2 } } \\ { 1 } & { b } & { b ^ { 2 } } \\ { 1 } & { c } & { c ^ { 2 } } \end{array} \right| = 0 \\ = ( 1 + a b c ) [ ( a - b ) ( b - c ) ( c - a ) ] = 0 \)

Because a, b, c are different, the second factor cannot be zero. Hence, option (a),1+abc= 0, is correct.
question_plain_title: If are unequal what is the condition that the value of the following determinant is zero
explanation_plain_text:
Splitting the determinant into two determinants, we get,

Because a, b, c are different, the second factor cannot be zero. Hence, option (a),1+abc= 0, is correct.

quest_title: The quantities a,(b )and(c )are related with \(\text{x}\) by formula \(X = \cfrac{ab^2}{C^3}\) Where percentage error in measuring a, b and c are \(\pm 1\)%, \(\pm 3\)% and\(\pm 2\)% respectively. The percentage error in \(\text{x}\) can be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{X} &=\cfrac{\mathrm{ab}^{2}}{\mathrm{C}^{3}} \Rightarrow \cfrac{\Delta \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{x}} \\ &=\pm\left(\cfrac{\Delta \mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{a}}+2 \times \cfrac{\Delta \mathrm{b}}{\mathrm{b}}+3 \cfrac{\Delta \mathrm{C}}{\mathrm{C}}\right) \\ &=\pm(1 \%+2 \times 3 \%+3 \times 2 \%) \\ &=\pm 13 \% \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A uniform wire of resistance 36 \(\Omega\) is bent in the form of circle. The effective resistance across the points A and B such that AB makes \(60^\circ\) at centre is
explanation_txt:
Let \(r\) be the resistance of total length of circular wire. The resistance of smaller arc \(\mathrm{AB}, r_{1}=\cfrac{r}{6}=\cfrac{36}{6}=6 \Omega\)

The resistance of bigger arc AB

\(r_{2}=\cfrac{5}{6} r=\cfrac{5}{6} \times 36=30 \Omega\)

Resistances \(r_{1}\) and \(r_{2}\) are in parallel between points \(A\) and \(B\) . Therefore,

\(\cfrac{1}{R}=\cfrac{1}{R_{1}}+\cfrac{1}{R_{2}}\)

\(\cfrac{1}{R}=\cfrac{1}{6}+\cfrac{1}{30}\)

\(\therefore R=5 \Omega\)

quest_title: The velocity of an electron in the second orbit oftenly inoised sodium atom (atomic number Z = 11) is v. The velocity of an electron in its fifth orbit will be.
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{v}=\cfrac{\mathrm{C}}{137} \times \cfrac{11}{2} \ldots \ldots \ldots(\mathrm{i})\)
\(\mathrm{v}^{\prime}=\cfrac{\mathrm{C}}{137} \times \cfrac{11}{5} \ldots \ldots \ldots\) (ii)
\(\therefore \cfrac{\mathrm{v}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{v}}=\cfrac{2}{5}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{v}^{\prime}=\cfrac{2 \mathrm{v}}{5}\)

quest_title: The word 'alkali' used for alkali metals indicates
explanation_txt:
The name alkali came from Arabic language which means “The Ashes”.

The Arabs used this term for these metals because they found that the Ashes of plants were composed chiefly of sodium and potassium.

quest_title: Which pair of atomic numbers represents s-block elements?
explanation_txt:
3 = 2,1  -> Lithium

12 = 2,8,2 -> Magnesium

Last electron enters s orbital in both the elements.

quest_title: Let the function f : R -R be defined by f(x) = 2x + cosx. Then f
explanation_txt:
\(f(x)=2 x+\cos x\)
\(f^{\prime}(x)=2-\sin x>0 x \in R\)
\([-1 \leq \sin x \leq 1]\)
\(\therefore f\) is an increasing function

A body of mass 0.5kg is rotated in a horizontal circle of radius 80cm. The tension on the string if it makes 5 revolutions per second is
explanation_txt: \(\mathrm{T}=\mathrm{mr} \omega^{2}=0.5 \times 0.8(2 \pi \mathrm{f})^{2}=394.8 \mathrm{N}\)

quest_title: A box of mass 10 kg rest on a horizontal floor. A force \(\text{F}\) is applied on the box at an angle 30\(\circ\) with horizontal. If the coefficient of friction between box and floor is 0.2, then minimum force required to slide the box horizontally is
explanation_txt:
\(F \cos \theta=\mu(m g-F \sin \theta)\)
\(F=\cfrac{\mu m g}{\cos \theta+\mu \sin \theta}\)

\(F=\cfrac{0.2 \times 10 \times 10}{\cos 30+0.2 \sin 30}=20.7 \mathrm{N}\)

explanation_txt: \(\mathrm{F}_{\max }=\mathrm{mr} \omega^{2}=50 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.1 \times\left(\cfrac{2 \pi}{T}\right)^{2}\)

quest_title: For cooking the food, which of the following type of utensil is most suitable
explanation_txt: For cooking utensils, low specific heat is preferred for its material as it should need less heat to raise its temperature. Moreover, it should have high conductivity because it should transfer heat quickly.

quest_title: Length of a metal rod is 100cm at 15\({}^{0}\)c. The temperature is raised to 165\({}^{0}\)c, its length become 100.12cm. The cubical expansivity of metal is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \gamma=3 \alpha &=3 \times \cfrac{l_{165}-l_{15}}{l_{15} \times(165-15)} \\ &=3 \cfrac{(100.12-100)}{100 \times 150} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: The focal length of a convex lens is 'f'. An object is placed at a distance x from its first focus. The ratio of size of real image to that of the object is
explanation_txt: \(\mathrm{m}=\cfrac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{u}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}+\mathrm{x}-\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{x}}\)

quest_title: Two organ pipes, each closed at are end, gives 5 beats per second when emitting their fundamental notes. If their lengths are in the ratio of 50:51, their fundamental frequencies (in Hz) are
explanation_txt:
\( \mathrm{f} \propto 1/l \\ \therefore \, \mathrm{f} \times \mathrm{l} = \text{constant} \)

If \(l_1 = 50\) & \(f_1=f\) Then \(l_2 = 51\) and \(f_2=f-5\)

\(\mathrm{f} \times 50=(\mathrm{f}-5) \times 51\)

\(\mathrm{f}=51 \times 5=255\)

\(\begin{align} \therefore \, & \mathrm{f}_{1}=255 \\ & \mathrm{f}_{2}=250 \end{align}\)

i.e. 250 and 255

Also if \(1_{1}=51\) and \(f_{1}=f\)

Then, \(l_{2}=50\) and \(f_{2}=f+5\)

i.e. \(f \times 51=(f+5) \times 50\)

\(\quad f=250\)

\(\therefore \,250 \,\&\, 255\)
question_plain_title: Two organ pipes, each closed at are end, gives 5 beats per second when emitting their fundamental notes. If their lengths are in the ratio of 50:51, their fundamental frequencies (in Hz) are
explanation_plain_text:
If & Then and

i.e. 250 and 255

Also if and

Then, and

i.e.
